Entry Fee: No fixed lake entry fee; boat rides/stays have charges
Accessibility: Road access via Moirang; floating islands require boat
Guided Tours: Local boat operators, homestays arrange tours
Parking: At lake shores / tourist home / resort areas
Nearby Amenities: Homestays, resorts on Thanga or Sendra islands; cafeterias
Special Notes: Unique for its floating phumdis (biomass); adjacent to Keibul Lamjao National Park

Accessibility: Jeep safari, guided walks on floating biomass; not wheelchair-friendly
Special Notes: World’s only floating national park; habitat of the endangered Sangai (“dancing deer”)

Accessibility: Road accessible; walking inside fort; not fully wheelchair-friendly
Special Notes: Seat of Manipur’s former kingdom; includes temples, relics, and INA Museum section

Best Time to Visit: Oct–Apr (festivals like Holi celebrated with grandeur)
Accessibility: Easily accessible by road; temple has steps (not fully wheelchair-friendly)
Special Notes: Historic 19th-century temple patronized by Manipur’s royal family

Nearest Railway Station: Dimapur (Nagaland) is nearest major railhead; local connectivity by road from Imphal
Nearest Bus Stand: Local bus to Thoubal; then onward local transport to Khongjom
Accessibility: Road access; some walking; hillock; moderate
Nearby Amenities: Shops / tea stalls, restrooms; lodging in nearby towns
Special Notes: Commemorates the Battle of Khongjom (1891) and Major Paona Brajabashi

Nearest Railway Station: Similar to others; likely Dimapur as major point; local roads from Imphal
Nearest Bus Stand: Bus to Sekta via Imphal East local buses
Accessibility: Walking across archaeological mounds; not wheelchair-friendly likely
Guided Tours: When arranged via State Archaeology Dept / local guides
Parking: Basic near village; not large structured parking
Nearby Amenities: Nearby villages, simple lodging / food; restrooms basic
Special Notes: Known for the excavation of burial mounds; “living museum” concept

Nearest Railway Station: You would use Dimapur + road or nearest local station
Nearest Bus Stand: In Imphal, local buses / taxis to Iroisemba
Nearest Airport: Imphal Airport — within city / short drive
Best Time to Visit: Summer months and dry season; early day for active animals
Accessibility: Well maintained paths; enclosures; walkable; may be partial for wheelchairs
Guided Tours: Zoo staff / local guides may explain animals
Parking: Likely available near zoo entrance; charges small / not clearly documented
Nearby Amenities: Restrooms, refreshment stalls; shops; hotels in Imphal
Special Notes: Houses rare and endangered species including Sangai; important for conservation

Nearest Railway Station: Nearest major via road (Imphal to Moirang); local stations are minor
Nearest Bus Stand: Moirang town; buses / taxis from Imphal
Entry Fee: Not clearly documented in public sources
Accessibility: Well constructed complex; walking paths; some climbing small elevations; not all sections wheelchair-friendly
Guided Tours: Museum guides likely available; local guides for historical context
Parking: Parking available at complex; basic facilities
Nearby Amenities: Lodging in Moirang; food shops; restrooms
Special Notes: Moirang is significant because INA first hoisted Indian flag under Netaji in Moirang in 1944

Nearest Railway Station: Nearest major stations would be in Nagaland / Dimapur side
Nearest Bus Stand: Local towns near Senapati district & border regions
Nearest Airport: Imphal Airport + road to border areas; or using Nagaland side airports
Timings: Trek accessible in daylight; camps night stay for trekkers
Entry Fee: Not documented (some trekking permit may be needed)
Accessibility: Trekking required; moderate to difficult; physically demanding; not wheelchair friendly
Guided Tours: Local trekking groups/guides; organizers especially from Kohima or Imphal/Bordertown
Nearby Amenities: Camping huts, tents; small village shops; limited lodging near base camps
Special Notes: Famous trekking valley; “valley of flowers” seasonal bloom; fragile ecosystem
Famous for traditional pottery, local brew, and cultural museum

Accessibility: Short hike required from parking; not wheelchair-friendly
Special Notes: Picturesque falls surrounded by dense forests — picnic spot

Entry Fee: Not documented (may vary for wildlife entry)
Nearby Amenities: Eco huts, small shops in Tamenglong town
Special Notes: Known for migratory birds, local legends, and scenic landscape
Maintains 110+ rare orchid species native to Manipur

Guided Tours: Forest guides & local tribes provide eco-tours
Special Notes: Only habitat of the rare Siroi lily (Lilium mackliniae) — state flower of Manipur

Accessibility: Short trek to cave; inside paths slippery — not wheelchair-friendly
Special Notes: Known as “Khangkhui Mangsor”; Paleolithic remains found

Accessibility: Road + short trek; cave exploration moderate difficulty
Special Notes: Prehistoric significance; 5 km long cave with multiple chambers
Known as “Stonehenge of Manipur” — village of giant standing monoliths tied to tribal rituals

Accessibility: Fully road accessible; building partially wheelchair-friendly
Nearby Amenities: Cafes, shops, government guest houses nearby
Special Notes: Exhibits rare manuscripts, tribal ornaments, costumes, royal artifacts, and zoological specimens
